Instructions

To use the Badminton Match Simulator, you will need to input values into the simulator and press the "Run simulation" button.

By default, the simulator has values preset to use the current badminton rule standards as of 2023 (First to 2 games in a match, win by 2, cap at 30 points, and rally scoring). If you ever want to revert back to the default values, simply refresh the page.



Down below, I will describe the meaning of each of the possible inputs into the simulator:

1. Point Win Rate % - The probability that the player will win any given rally. You can change the input for Player 1 and the Point Win Rate of Player 2 will automatically be calculated as 100 - {your value}.

2. Starting Score - The score that the player will start with at the beginning of every game. Note that this is not the starting score of the players in a match, just for every game. A match consists of one or more games.

3. Number of Games to Win a Match - The number of games a player needs to win a match. For example, in a best of 3, you need to win 2 games to win the match.

4. Number of Points to Win a Game - The number of points a player needs to win a game as long as no extra points are required. For example, the current badminton standard ends games at 21 points as long as the player has at least 2 more points than the other player.

5. Number of Points to Cap the Game At - The maximum number of points a player can have in a game. If a player reaches this score, they automatically win the game no matter what.

6. Number of Points a Player Should Win By - The point gap needed between scores in order to win a game. This is ignored if a player reaches the point cap.

7. Scoring system - There are 2 types of scoring: rally and side-out. In rally scoring, a player is awarded a point no matter who is serving if that player wins the rally. In side-out scoring, players are only awarded points when they are the ones serving.

8. Server - The first server in the match. The first server can be especially important in side-out scoring systems. Note that for each game after the first game of a match, the winner of the previous game will be considered as the first server.

9. Number of Matches to Simulate - The number of badminton matches that will be simulated.
